I know this is early access and things change, but this could take the game in a totally new direction.

Early Access.  
Tree of Life is Early Access.  I need to stress how important it is that everyone who plays this game remembers this fact.
We have paid to get involved in the games development. Massively Multiplayer.

PvP

Most of the remaining players whom I've met have no desire to cause trouble and actually focus on building care packages or helping out newbies. RPG

Tree of Life looks like a casual sandbox RPG game with faction wars and base building. However, that's only how the game advertises itself. In reality, it is a game caters and rewards hardcore players who join large groups while inadvertently punishing guilds in small numbers (3 or fewer). The game revolves around constant deterioration of equipment and supplies, in addition to a mandatory tax that is paid weekly in real time, which makes it too time consuming for solo/duo players to keep up.

The game provides 21 skills (called masteries) to gain up to 50 levels in, while allowing 320 total levels spread between economic (living) and combat. This means you can max out 6 skills only and combat will require you to level 2-3 of these skills, leaving you 3-4 economic skills to choose to max out. While this sounds like a great thing to encourage interaction and a living community, it means soloing/duoing is essentially impossible. Arrow/Cannon towers require carpentry to build and blacksmithing/tinkering to maintain. Your armour and weapons will require blacksmithing, tailoring, and tinkering. Those skills alone means solo players will have zero combat skills if they wish to build their base, and that means they can not kill the enemies required to get the materials.

Weapons and armor constantly break, which is a good thing to keep the economy moving. However, because they break so often and quickly, you will likely go through 2-3 weapons in the process of gathering materials to make another 5, not including any hits you take to your armor and bags. Armor is difficult to maintain and you usually can only afford to maintain the lower level suits, and sometimes not even those. As you level up to higher levels, you will be able to maintain them  better and longer, but will still find yourself farming 5-6 hours to counter maintenance in order to have 2 hours of actual fun playtime.

There are three factions that you choose from when making your character. These factions can attack other factions, but can't attack their own. There is a faction chat in game, but even on the American server it is usually dominated by French or Chinese and getting a response to a question or discussion in English is actually a very rare thing. If you're a small guild or group, don't expect to  rely on help from others in Faction chat as they likely will not understand you, or you will not understand them.

The game has a heavy advantage to those who are willing to pay for in-game items in the premium store. $25 will get you a mount that you never need to maintain other than feed. You can get a mount in game, however it will not have the built-in light source that premium mounts come with and will die after a set number of uses, forcing you to gather materials for another one. If you're not a rancher player, then you will never make your own mounts. Bags can be purchased for $10-15 and provide extra inventory space that doesn't break. Bags crafted in game will degrade just like armor and weapons. What makes this dangerous is if one breaks while holding items, all of the items spill out. This is not a concern for the player who pays real cash.

Overall, Tree of Life is not a game I can recommend. I have put in a great number of hours hoping the game would get better as many online games do. Sadly, there is no end game and the grind never changes.

If you are someone who is willing to grind hard and push past obstacles in order to get value out of their time, buy this game. DO NOT, however, buy this game if you are looking for a peaceful PvE survival experience. You should also make sure that you either:

[b]------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/b]

Tree of Life is a Runescape-esque MMORPG with a heavy emphasis on what sets it apart from its competitors - Clash of Clans style base building and defense in an open factions world. It boasts over 15 different skillpaths, the ability to create 
massive guilds with up to 30 members, and medieval-style PvP. Overall, my experience with this game has been good, but that doesn't mean I dont have my gripes with it.

This game is not, will not, and cannot be, without major fundamental changes, a singleplayer PvE game. Though it is technically an option, you're guaranteed to not have fun unless you have less than 80 IQ and enjoy weeks of braindead WORK (not play) plus a hard limit (6 maxed out skills) on what you can do with one character.

[b]IN ORDER FROM BEST ASPECTS TO WORST:[/b]

I experienced this game with a small guild of 4 regular players including me. With each of us taking up different skillpaths and investing similar amounts of time into the game, we had a great deal of fun for about 100 hours, when it got too hardcore even for the few of us seasoned MMORPG players. We were able to organize and participate in a huge raid consisting of players from different guilds, which I consider one of the highlights of my time playing. Moments like these lead me to believe that Tree of Life is a game that strives on large groups / communities. Guilds aren't called guilds for no reason. When you max out yours with 30 people, they feel and work like, well, guilds.

Like every other review on this page says, the game has a great amount of potential. At the moment, I don't see the devs taking any risks while they try to satisfy the community, fresh off the game's 1.0.0 release, but I do believe it's a future possibility. Though many of the people I've talked to have said that the devs are loose cannons, I was able to observe them add guards to the newbie areas after backlash. It seems like a step in the right direction to listen to the playerbase.

Soundtrack is pretty good. It's nutty at times, but it definitely fits the aesthetic and adds positively to the game.

I have no problems with the PvP mechanics. Tree of Life embraces its simplistic, Minecraft-esque combat with just enough aspects to make it interesting. I do have a problem, however, with the weaponskills. Every weapon has a special effect, but in the end they all deal the same damage. Other than that, spears don't even hit enemies and bows do little to no damage at all.

Game progression seems and feels clunky. I can't quite put my finger on why, but I'm guessing it has to do with some skills requiring a disproportionate amount of work compared to others.

Considering the abnormally high amount of firewood needed to do anything, literally everyone that plays will get their Logging level to 50, which they will, in turn, need. Even after this happens, cutting down trees will still take too long to account for how much wood you require. Logging (and by extension Mining) should simply be removed from the game, instead having trees be affected by how strong your weapon is.
